article.headline: Tennessee 69, Arkansas 65
article.story: KNOXVILLE, Tenn. (AP) -- Tennessee coach Buzz Peterson recently asked his point guard to shoot the ball more, and C.J. Watson picked the right time to follow those instructions. Watson hit a 3-pointer with 1:05 left and Tennessee held on to beat Arkansas 69-65 Wednesday night. "I'm proud of our team, that we were two possessions down and managed to pull it out," Peterson said. "C.J. Watson's 3-pointer was huge." Scooter McFadgon scored 19 points, including two free throws in the final minute, while Watson added 14 points and Brandon Crump had 13 points and 10 rebounds for the Volunteers (12-8, 4-5 Southeastern Conference), who snapped a two-game losing streak. Tennessee led by nine with 6:34 to go, but Matt Jones hit a 3 to start a 13-2 run for Arkansas (11-10, 3-7). Ronnie Brewer's breakaway layup following a Tennessee turnover gave the Razorbacks a 65-63 lead with 2:55 left. After several missed shots by both teams, Watson sank the 3-pointer from the corner. "I thought it was kind of off to the right," Watson said. Arkansas couldn't score again and tried to stop the clock by fouling. McFadgon went to the line with 25.3 seconds left, and Crump sank the first of two free throws with 12.7 seconds to go to seal it. The Razorbacks are 0-6 on the road in the SEC but came close to breaking their losing streak despite shooting 36.8 percent from the field (25-of-68). Arkansas has lost four straight to the Vols. "We're playing good basketball, particularly on the road. We had ourselves in position to win," Arkansas coach Stan Heath said. "We played our hearts out, but the shots didn't fall." Tennessee's defense was shaky at times, and the Vols had trouble finishing shots inside, including dunks. Olu Famutimi had a career-high 18 points to lead the Razorbacks. Michael Jones added 13 and Billy Pharis and Jonathan Modica each scored 11. McFadgon scored 15 of his points in the first half -- all on 3-pointers. He was scoreless in the second half until he made a jumper with 4:39 to go after Tennessee had built a nine-point lead. Arkansas adjusted by using a box-and-one against McFadgon in the second half. McFadgon, who leads the league by averaging 21 points in SEC games, was not wearing protective padding over his right, shooting hand for the first time since he injured it in December. "With it on my hand, I've been limited with some of the things I can do. I took it off," he said. Arkansas had tied it at 50 with 10 minutes left, but the Vols went on a 9-0 run. Modica scored all his points in the first half while Brewer, who was averaging 13 points a game, didn't score until he hit two free throws with 4:58 remaining. He finished with five points.
